Comentario:
Currently, I'm at Chapter 6, and so far, so great. (I will not tackle any story-related or character development as I am not finished with the game, and this review is purely about gameplay.) I enjoyed playing this game and had fun with the majority of gameplay mechanics. First, the Combat (which is my favorite aspect of the game) is much more dynamic and improved compared to the first part (Remake). With the addition of Synergy Skills and Synergy Abilities, you have more options to experiment with how your party can work together. As every enemy encounter requires you to adjust your strategy and adapt, Exploration, while repetitive, was still enjoyable for the most part. For example, unlocking combat via the Combat Simulator to gain rewards by defeating special mobs in a large Zone Area. Speaking of Zone Area, while it's not as vast as a typical big Open World, it is still a pretty large area that will take you hours to explore and complete all the side quests in one zone. Mini-Games—two words: Queen's Blood—an addicting card game that will consume much of your time. There are a lot of mini-games you'll encounter, and I'm only at Chapter 6, but I've already seen plenty of them, most of which are **** above are my Pros in this game.Cons: While I don't particularly care about the graphics, I'll just leave a comment for those who prioritize them. Regarding Graphics options, expect to play at 30 fps (no more than that). You can choose to play at 60 fps in performance mode, but the graphics will be a bit rougher, and expect some blurriness. While mini-games are fun, sometimes they become tedious and annoying, especially the ones tied up in the main quest. So far, those are the only major cons I can mention about the game.

Overall the Pros completely shatter the Cons, the game is highly recommended even if you haven't played the OG ) FF7 (1997), and it is considerably better than the Remake (First Part).

10/10

A true love letter to FF and games in general. Great tone, characters, worldbuilding, combat, atmosphere, cities, exploration, diversity of content. It's emotionally gripping and powerful. Comentario: This game is simply a masterpiece. The lands are so vast and the characters are full of life. The combat system goes into great depth with every member being special and the abilities to let characters dominate together is just plain awesome. Yes, the graphics/resolution comes up short, but the amount of things to do and the side quests actually being fun with npcs finally having personality makes up for it entirely. I'm expecting more updates to improve those factors, so don't hold yourself up on the visuals too harshly. Despite that, there is very beautiful environments and jaw dropping sceneries filled with life, epic moments, and a big amount of fun exploring. The story is also beautiful and you feel the bonds grow with your companions. Some parts can seem confusing, but that is definitely the plan to set up for the third installment. I can't wait to see what the future hold.

Comentario:
First of all, the haters shouldnt be allowed giving 0 score for obvious reasons. These are the same vocal minority who are miserable full of issues and like ruining the fun for everyone. 
Im gaming for over 35 years and been there through all gaming generations and all ive got to say about this game is that for me its one of the best AAA modern games ive ever played and the best PS5 game so far! An absolute masterpiece and a total must play. 
Some salty people are in denial about what a remake is. They are not true fans of the game. I loved this game exactly how i loved the original back in 1997. And what if there are minor changes to the story? 90-95℅ its the same game story wise. The battle is way better than the original in any way possible and this comes from someone who grow up with turn based rpgs. Music is even better. Graphics and performance showing PS5's true power. Games are evolving either we like it or not. The original is there for everyone to play. I wish other companies could do half of the ammount of hard work, love and dedication thats been put into this game. This is the vision that developers  wanted to do with the game all those years but technical wise wasnt possible. Of course all the content of the original game couldnt fit in just one game. I take anytime a complete game with every little detail as possible in more than one part rather just one rushed and short game which eventually would lack content.
I enjoyed every single moment of this game and nostalgic tears have been shed many times in this amazing experience.
Congratulations to Square for bringing us this project to life and made the dream come true! 
Thank you from the bottom of my heart for everything and cant wait for the final part in 2028!

Comentario: I score **** game is able to simultaneously express an extraordinarily gorgeous and expansive world and unique character detail, a high quality fusion never before seen in RPGs. There are many side stories and subquests, but the game maintains an optimal balance without making the player feel too powerful even when taking side trips.There are some problems with the UI in a few areas, such as the chocobo's sniffing controls, but the overall control and freedom are excellent, without compromising the complex RPG-like customization.Because FF7 can be enjoyed as a completely new experience despite being a remake, it can be considered a candidate for Game of the Year **** music is better than the previous FF7 Remake, with diverse and pleasant listening arrangements.

Comentario: It still pushes story elements that are just non-functional or out-right awful (characters like Roche are back e.g.). The Reunion robed guys are constantly shoved in your face repeatedly when it really doesn’t even make sense to include them and they really aren’t interesting at all, bringing nothing to the story (Rude brings them in on a helicopter for Shinra at some point in the game, wtf). They look like drug addicts that escaped from a Florida Comicon so they aren’t even really that “cool”.  Doesn’t really deserve a 92 and is a blemish compared to the source material as far as the story goes. The story definitely has a lot of cringe Disney movie moments that really sour the seriousness of the original (while it had comedic moments, they were actually funny. Most of this isn’t).. Gameplay-wise it’s obviously superior to the original and Remake both, but let’s face it: we were mainly here for the story and the music. Music is a mixed bag of remixed tracks of the original with some new tracks that aren’t too shabby. It’s no GOTY, but it’s a solid game and worth the money considering how long it is. Just know it’s a mixed bag if you’re a fan of the original and didn’t think Remake was anything better than good. If you thought Remake was bad, however, this isn’t going to impress you in a different way. I think the art direction is the real improvement on Remake here, and obviously the gameplay. I’m at 13 hours and the more I get into this the greater my concerns become, making me question the $70 price point. Gotta say the last half of the game makes up for the slow first half, pushing this into 8/10 territory. I’ve updated my review accordingly.

Comentario:
I was really worried when I learned the open zones concept the developers were going with. I was worried it might be to checklisted busy work, I was also worried it might be too empty like FF16.

Couldn’t be anymore pleasantly surprised when I actually played the game itself. The open area was huge but not too huge that it became just beautiful sceneries with an empty world. The tasks and mini games you were given with were also varied so much that they don’t get boring easily.

Onto the combat, I am so happy to see they’ve built upon what they came up with in its 4yo predecessor and made it more diversified and fun. Each character being so different (and likable!) istruly a massive triumphant for the devs. The combat has so much depths and potential customisation that I wasn’t left feeling like I was just attacking and dodging and waiting for cooldowns to end.

All in all, a truly excellent game!

Comentario:
Imagine a bunch of idiots on here giving the score 0-3 because the resolution looks lame on performance mode and the 30fps choppiness of graphics mode.  

Behind those things, we have an amazing, GotY contender in FF7 Rebirth.  The core of this game improves on the first in every way possible.  

The only reason to knock off a couple points is for Square's lame attempt at making this game look modern on new gen hardware.  Other than that it's a rock solid, nostalgic trip down memory lane that every fan of JRPGs should experience.  

Don't even bother reading the crap reviews and low scores.  They're just crying about the graphics, which absolutely does not ruin this game at all.

Comentario:
"Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" is a testament to the enduring legacy and love that fans and creators alike hold for the original "Final Fantasy VII," a game that originally graced the world over 25 years ago. This remake is not merely a retelling but a reimagining that breathes new life into the beloved story, characters, and world of Gaia, 
demonstrating an unparalleled commitment to both preserving and enhancing the essence of the original.From the onset, it's clear that the developers at Square Enix have poured their hearts and souls into this project. The attention to detail is meticulous, from the reimagined yet faithful character designs to the expansive, beautifully rendered environments that feel both nostalgic and new. The developers have walked a fine line between innovation and preservation, updating the gameplay mechanics with a modern action-RPG twist that retains the strategic depth of the original's turn-based system, making it accessible to newcomers and satisfying for **** narrative depth of "Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" is where the game truly shines. The developers have taken great care to expand on the storylines of beloved characters, providing new insights and emotional depth that were not as explored in the original game. This approach enriches the overall experience, making every moment feel significant and every character's journey more **** music and sound design deserve special mention. The iconic score has been reimagined with orchestral arrangements that evoke a wide range of emotions, from nostalgia to excitement, enhancing every scene and battle. The voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters to life in a way that text alone could never achieve.However, what makes "Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" truly remarkable is its ability to resonate with players on a personal level. It's a journey that reflects on themes of love, loss, and the fight against insurmountable odds, themes that are timeless and universal. The game manages to evoke a sense of wonder and adventure, while also providing a space for reflection on the human condition and our impact on the **** conclusion, "Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" is more than a game; it's a labor of love that honors its source material while forging its own path. It's a rare piece of art

Comentario:
A decidedly mixed-bag at 40+ hours in.

What is there to say about FFVII Rebirth? It feels less like the continued effort to 'remake' FFVII, and more like a videogame adaptation of a 100+ issue manga adaptation of FFVII. Gone is the more careful tone-crafting of VII remake and a pin-point focus on narrative, replaced with a wild mishmash of tone, an unfocused narrative meted out in misshapen, uneven chunks, dated open world design... and mini-games. So many mini-games.

Personally, I find the weird tonal imbalance to be the most off-putting aspect of play so far. Forty plus hours in, and FFVII Rebirth has spent ~90% of the game attempting to be a whacky, hilarious road trip/beach episode with Cloud and the gang-- only be to interrupted every so often with baldly-stated melodrama or cryptic, unexplained nonsense that only remotely makes sense if you've fully 'bought in' to the game's expanded media landscape. Want to know what the **** is going on? Well, play these four to five games, watch this movie, etc etc.

The 'open world' focus, which felt (mostly) fine at first becomes bone-weary after the first two dozen hours or so. Dated 'tower' mechanics to unlock points of interest, which consist of either monster fights, mini-games, or even more simple QTE events which take 2-3 times longer than they have any right to be.

Far worse than this dated design, however, is that remake often ties wholesale completion of these open-world objectives to sidequests, which doubly-function as a relationship mechanic for party members. Want Tifa to 'like' you more? Better get to playing Yet Another Final Fantasy Card Game. 

Sidequests themselves run the gamut from mostly inoffensive and simple to soul-crushingly bloated and frustrating. One such sidequest, which would raise affinity with a male party member, first required the player to complete every open-world 'mako shrine' event-- four or five locations, spread across two zones of a map, where the player participates in a3-button QTE event to 'finish' the shrine. Finishing these shrines unlocks another open-world event, where the player must leave the vehicle transport they've been given to summon their chocobo, to use the bird to dig for 'transmuter chips'--basically, in-game crafting recipes that allow the player to craft healing items, equippable accessories... and items required for side-quests. 

So, once you've found all the towers, which lets you find all the shrines, you do yet another open-world objective to find a crafting recipe (and then make sure you have the requisite materials to craft the side-quest item), and once you have the item needed for the sidequest, the quest actually begins! And what *is* this quest?

This quest involves you going to three locations, spread across the map, and using the crafted item (a trap) at these three locations, attempting to capture a creature. Upon leaving the third and final trap, you return to the first trap you laid, fight monsters, and then go do the same thing at the second trap you laid. And then the third. And then the quest is finished! Congratulations! For this hour and half-ish amount of work, you get... a one-star materia, and barret's 'affinity' for you goes from a green smiley face to... a green smiley face.

And this is what FFVII rebirth is. Over and over and over again, which giant chunks of cutscenes that are either cavity-inducing cute & sweet, or borderline incomprehensible melodrama shoveled in between.

Die-hard FFVII fans and lovers of all things FFVII-related are likely to find an enjoyable enough time here-- Rebirth is a weaponized amalgamation of nostalgia and fanservice that feels especially designed for them. Anyone less enchanted by Cloud, Sephiroth, and the whole gang might find significantly less joy in the experience.

After just shy of thirty years dealing with this crew, I know I am.

Comentario:
This game is phenomenal. SE really knocked it out  the park with this one, & the devs should be proud of themselves for delivering this fantastic sequel in the FFVIIR trilogy. 
The combat and story are fantastic, and the music is perfection.
The character development also shines brightly in this game, and I love how some of the side quests even come with their own backstory. Usually NPC’s are minor characters, but in this game they actually feel like they have more significance, and thanks to this it really makes this a world fighting for. 
The main characters have such amazing bonds with eachother, & they’re a group of people I fell in love with even more than I did in Remake. Some scenes also really pull on your heartstrings. Lots of emotion and care was put in to creating this game, &  this is everything a Final Fantasy game should be.
There are some graphical texturing issues in the open world; but to be fair it’s such a large & mostly open world, and these are minor issues  that don’t bother me at all. There are issues in other similar games too, and It didn’t get in the way of the experience for me. Talking about graphics; the cinematic scenes are beautiful, and the locations you explore are extremely detailed & stunning.
Overall, FFVII Rebirth is a masterpiece, and I’m beyond excited to see what SE have in store for the final game in the FFVII Remake trilogy, along with the conclusion to this reimagined, and gripping, story.

Comentario: I cannot believe they pulled this off I am 25 hours in and cannot express the crazy amount of fanfare this games throws at you. You can easily spend 20/30 hours in the FIRST area, the grassland. Just to summarize amazing enemy design, extremely cool synergy moves, battles and combat are so fun it just leaves you wanting more. The story well let’s just say it’s based on one of the best of ALL time. I have only found some very very small flaws in the game, the chocobo maneuverability is a little lacking, not enough battles spread throughout the amazing maps, would be so much nicer if things were picked up automatically instead of always pressing triangle. These are my only complaints but non of them overshadow this masterpiece. This so far is my favorite FF of all time and that’s coming from a die hard ff fan that has played every single entry and spin off. Go buy this game immediately.

Comentario:
FF7 Rebirth attempts to reimagine the beloved classic, but falls short in several key areas. The game introduces a padded overworld reminiscent of Ubisoft titles, which detracts from the sense of exploration and adventure that a traditional overworld would have provided. This decision feels like a missed opportunity to capture the essence of the original game's exploration.

Furthermore, while the original FF7's storyline was complex and engaging, FF7 Rebirth's narrative feels unnecessarily convoluted in comparison. The changes made to the story often miss the mark, with iconic moments such as a certain characters death being mishandled, turning what was once a poignant and emotional event into something of a joke.

However, one aspect of FF7 Rebirth that shines is its music. The soundtrack remains a highlight, beautifully reimagining the iconic melodies of the original game and providing a nostalgic backdrop to the player's journey.

Overall, FF7 Rebirth struggles to live up to the legacy of its predecessor. While it offers some redeeming qualities, such as its exceptional music, the game's padded overworld, convoluted story, and mishandled narrative changes ultimately leave it feeling like a missed opportunity for fans of the original.

Comentario:
Phenomenal video game from Hamaguchi and the team at CBU1. I hope to see a mainline title or a new IP from this team after the Remake project.

The rest of my review will be, more or less, a review of those who refuse to unveil their rose tinted glasses for the original game.

I see a lot of users giving scathing reviews less than 48 hours after release. This tells me three things. 1: They did not take their time with the game in anyway, if they even played it at all. 2: They just straight up watched the ending (or read spoilers) and just wanted to see if they should review bomb, and lastly 3: They ignored everything that happened in 2020's FF7: Remake and thought, for some bewildering reason, that they would get something different with this ending.

Step back for a moment and analyze the original game that we all hold dearly to our hearts without bias. Was that game perfect? Of course not. Was that game padded out in many places? Well yes, it was. Was that plot straight forward, believable, and easy to understand, especially as an adolescent? Absolutely not, in any way. In these ways the remake project stays faithful.

On the other hand, what did the original do so well that made us fall in love with it? The world. The music. The combat. Of course, and most of all, the characters. In these terms, the remake project also stays faithful to, and at times surpasses, the original game. 

This trilogy, to be sure, will be a wild ride with the characters we fell in love and grew up with-  again.

Comentario:
The first time the series has felt innovative in a long time. The open world has never felt this vast yet detailed and beautiful. The first area takes over 12 hours to fully explore.
Has the playful spirit that Final Fantasy is loved for. 
The soundtrack work is the best ever done in gaming; over 400 tracks that change themselves based on the context of what you are doing.
The side quests are now contextualized based on what character you are doing them with, exploring moments that make you care for them more deeply. 
The combat has been enhanced over Remake by a large amount.
Besides performance, they hit on absolute every front. 
If you have a PS5 just play it, the game will be looked back on as a classic.

Comentario:
One of the best Final Fantasy games ever made filled with a huge amount of unique, fun and  mesmerising side quest and mini games that don’t feel repetitive and instead add soo much to the world and journey you go on. 

The only note worthy negative is the blurry performance mode but does offer a silky 60 fps most of the time and a stunning graphics mode that locks at fps which is impressive considering the scale and scope of the open world. Would recommend to not only Final Fantasy fans but to anyone who loves massive open world type adventures filled with activity’s, side quests and extremely fun mini games and a deep story that all blends together soo well. Would recommend playing Final Fantasy Remake before jumping into Rebirth though as the mechanics and story connect together and by not playing the sequel to this game would leave anyone feel overwhelmed and confused from a story prospevtuve.

Comentario:
"Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" é uma obra-prima incontestável no mundo dos videogames, uma experiência que transcende as expectativas e redefine o que significa ser um jogo de RPG. 

Desde o momento em que o jogo começa, é evidente que estamos diante de algo especial. A Square Enix conseguiu, mais uma vez, elevar o padrão, trazendo para os fãs não apenas uma sequência digna do icônico "Final Fantasy VII", mas uma experiência que se destaca como um feito singular na indústria.A narrativa de "Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" é profunda e envolvente, capturando a essência do original enquanto introduz elementos novos e emocionantes que mantêm a história fresca e intrigante. Cada personagem é desenvolvido com cuidado e profundidade, permitindo que os jogadores formem conexões genuínas e significativas. As performances de voz são impecáveis, trazendo à vida cada personagem de maneira que é tanto autêntica quanto comovente.Visualmente, o jogo é um espetáculo à parte.

Os gráficos são de tirar o fôlego, com ambientes ricamente detalhados e personagens tão bem renderizados que parecem saltar da tela. A atenção aos detalhes é evidente em cada cenário, desde as ruas movimentadas de Midgar até os locais mais remotos e misteriosos que os jogadores têm a oportunidade de explorar.

A Square Enix demonstra uma habilidade notável em criar um mundo que é ao mesmo tempo vasto e cheio de maravilhas visuais.A jogabilidade de "Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" é uma combinação perfeita de ação e estratégia. 

O sistema de combate é inovador, oferecendo uma mistura dinâmica de ataques em tempo real e comandos táticos que exigem que os jogadores pensem rapidamente e planejem seus movimentos com cuidado. Isso, juntamente com a personalização profunda de personagens e equipamentos, garante que cada batalha seja tanto desafiadora quanto recompensadora.A trilha sonora é outra área onde "Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" brilha. Cada composição musical complementa perfeitamente os momentos do jogo, desde batalhas intensas até cenas emocionais, elevando a experiência geral a novos patamares. A música não apenas acompanha a jornada, mas também a enriquece, tornando cada momento ainda mais **** suma, "Final Fantasy VII Rebirth" é um sonho realizado para os fãs da série e um testemunho do que é possível alcançar no mundo dos videogames. Este jogo não é apenas uma continuação de uma história amada; é uma celebração de tudo que faz de "Final Fantasy" uma série lendária. Sem falhas aparentes, este título estabelece-se não apenas como uma obra-prima do gênero RPG, mas como um dos maiores jogos já criados.

A Square Enix nos entregou um presente incomparável, uma aventura que ficará conosco por muitos anos.

Comentario:
Swooning over a video game.
Rebirth is unreal.
(Fan of OG, Fan of Remake, Huge fan of Rebirth)
2 minor, MINOR, hiccups (with release build): The chocobo/climbing jumping is a little janky. Cloud and chocobos get interrupted often by overworld traversal
AND
The Lighting!! The lighting gets super dark or super bright, gradually depending on areas, and these are things that can be fixed in an update! So onto the good.
10/10 Mini games, 10/10 Pacing, 10/10 Characters (nostalgia, we know and love them), 10/10 "open world", 10/10 Soundtrack, 10/10 Combat, 10/10 sidequests, 10/10 voice acting... I only wish FFXVI (16) had more exploration like this and sidequests that didnt feel like a chore (and mini-games at all in 16!)

This is what FFXV (15) was aiming for, but got left unfinished. This is what FF13 wish it was... over a decade of ok-good finally birthed a game the fans want!
Being let down by Tears of the Kingdom and Breath of the Wild, I feel like Square Enix needed this win, anyone not swooning over this game is lying.

Comentario:
I'm currently in Chapter 4 so much to be played.  That said, this is one of the best five games I've played ranking in greatness alongside The Wild Hunt and Zero Dawn.  Chapter 1 can mostly be skipped if you did the demo and Chapter 2 offers an immerse open world experience that took me about 8 hours to fully complete.

The developers clearly took feedback from Remake and improved upon it to make Rebirth.  I appreciate having ease of movement with swift chocobos and an abundance of fast travel points.  The character development is well done, voice actors are exception, gameplay is exhilarating, and the music is as good as any game I've played.  I don't give out "10s" lightly, but this game has thus far earned it.  Hopefully the rest of the game and changes expected for the OG don't destroy the essence of what made it spectacular.

To the development team, very well done, and thank you!

Edit: Completed the game.  I finally completed the platinum trophy and it took 204 hours.  It's the hardest platinum I've done in a collection that includes the likes of Nioh, Sekiro, and Bloodborne.  The vast array of Hard Mode, virtual, and mini game challenges required is intense, sometimes it felt hopeless.  Many complaints from users focus on some mini games or difficulty to get the platinum, but none of that really plays into the main themes of the game, which is a solid 10.  

Anyone giving the game less than a 6 is simply being petty.
